terms.definition: Application Programming Interface - a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate and share data with each other.
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems.
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to see revision history and revert to previous versions.
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted online and accessed through web browsers.
Pre-configured processes that execute tasks automatically without manual intervention, reducing human error and increasing efficiency.
Documented procedures or code that define step-by-step instructions for testing specific functionality or features of a product.
Formal records and reports that demonstrate adherence to regulatory standards and industry requirements for auditing purposes.
A single, unified storage location where all related documents, files, and data are organized and accessible to authorized users.
The ability for multiple users to simultaneously work on and edit the same document with changes visible instantly to all participants.
Internet of Things - a network of physical devices embedded with sensors and software that can connect and exchange data over the internet.
A chronological record of all changes, access, and activities performed on documents or systems for compliance and security purposes.
Pre-designed document formats with standardized sections and layouts that ensure consistency and completeness across similar documents.
The ability to automatically refresh and synchronize document content in real-time as underlying data or linked information changes.
Coordination and communication between different departments or teams with varying expertise working toward common project goals.
The process of ensuring that products, processes, and documentation meet all applicable laws, standards, and industry regulations.
